overview: Bringing animals, plants or food into the UK - pet passports, plant health certificates, the rules around meat, dairy and fish products
title: Bringing food, animals or plants into the UK

table.body:
## Dogs, cats, ferrets and horses

You can bring your dog, cat or ferret into the UK without quarantine as long as they meet the rules of the [Pet Travel Scheme (PETS)](/take-pet-abroad "Taking your pet abroad"). 

There's a similar scheme for [horses](/horse-passport "Getting and using a horse passport").

## Other animals

Other animals that are brought into the UK must have an import licence. They must also stay in quarantine for 6 months after arriving in the UK. You must pay the cost of this.

See the [Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) website](http://www.defra.gov.uk/wildlife-pets/pets/travel/quarantine/ "Quarantine information: Defra"){:rel="external"} for the latest quarantine information.

## Non-native animals

There are rules you must follow when importing animals that aren't native to the UK.

$D
[Download Defra’s leaflet on importing non-native animals into the UK (PDF, 134KB.)](http://archive.defra.gov.uk/wildlife-pets/wildlife/management/non-native/documents/nn-import-leaflet.pdf "Importing animals into the UK"){:rel="external"}
$D

table.body:
You can bring in any plant material from countries within the European Union (EU) if it is:

+ grown in an EU country
+ free from pests and diseases
+ for your own use

If you're travelling from a country outside the EU, many products have weight and quantity restrictions or are banned completely unless you have a 'phytosanitary' (plant health) certificate. 

You can get the certificate from the plant health authorities in the country you're leaving. It proves your plants have been inspected, are free from dangerous pests and diseases, and are suitable to enter the UK.

The leaflet 'If in doubt, leave it out' has more information on which plant material you can bring in, and how much of each item is allowed.

$D
[Download 'If in doubt, leave it out' (PDF, 140KB)](http://www.fera.defra.gov.uk/plants/publications/documents/ifindoubt.pdf "Download 'If in doubt, leave it out'"){:rel="external"}
$D

If you have specific questions, contact the Food and Environment Research Agency (Fera) Plant Health Admin Support Team:

+ 0844 248 0071 from the UK (24 hours a day)
+ +44 1904 465645 from outside the UK (between 8am and 5pm Monday to Friday)

table.body:
What you can bring into the UK depends on whether you're travelling from within or outside the [European Union.](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"}

##Within the EU
If you're travelling from a country within the EU, you can bring in any meat, dairy or other animal products (eg fish, eggs and honey). 

You can also bring in fruit and vegetables.

##Outside the EU

%You can't bring meat, meat products, milk, dairy products or potatoes into the UK from most countries outside the EU.%

You can bring up to 2 kilograms (kg) of fruit and vegetables (except potatoes) into the UK as long as they are:

+ in personal baggage
+ for you and your family or friends - you can't sell them
+ free from signs of pests and diseases

You can also bring:

+ egg products, eggs and honey (2kg in total)
+ fish (20kg in total or one fish, whichever is the heaviest) - this must be fresh and gutted, cooked, cured, dried or smoked

For more details, see ['Bringing fruit, vegetable and plant products into the UK'](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageLibrary_PublicNoticesAndInfoSheets&propertyType=document&columns=1&id=HMCE_PROD_010869 "Bringing fruit, vegetable and plant products into the UK"){:rel="external"} and ['Bringing food products into the UK'.](http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/channelsPortalWebApp.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pageVAT_ShowContent&id=HMCE_PROD_010856&propertyType=document "Bringing food products into the UK"){:rel="external"}
